microCourses.title: Basics of Newtonian Physics
microCourses.description: Quick insights into Newton's fundamental laws of motion.

content.title: Newton's First Law: Inertia
content.markupContent:
### Law 1: The Law of Inertia

An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction *unless* acted upon by an unbalanced force.

**Think:** A hockey puck gliding on ice.

content.title: Newton's Second Law: F=ma
content.caption: Force equals mass times acceleration. More force = more acceleration!

content.title: Newton's Third Law: Action-Reaction
content.markupContent:
### Law 3: Action-Reaction

For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

**Example:** When you push a wall (action), the wall pushes back on you with equal force (reaction).

content.questionText: Which law explains why you feel pushed back into your seat when a car accelerates forward?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Your body wants to stay at rest (inertia).
content.feedbackIncorrect: Not quite. That's related to inertia (the First Law).

microCourses.title: Introduction to Cell Biology
microCourses.description: Explore the basic building blocks of life: cells.

content.title: Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic
content.markupContent:
### Two Main Types:

*   **Prokaryotic:** Simple cells (like bacteria) lacking a nucleus.
*   **Eukaryotic:** Complex cells (like plant and animal cells) with a nucleus and other organelles.

We are made of Eukaryotic cells!

content.title: Inside an Animal Cell
content.caption: Key organelles like the nucleus, mitochondria, and cell membrane.

content.title: The Nucleus: Control Center
content.markupContent:
### The Nucleus

Contains the cell's genetic material (DNA) and controls the cell's growth and reproduction.

content.title: Mitochondria: Powerhouse
content.markupContent:
### Mitochondria

Responsible for generating most of the cell's supply of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), used as a source of chemical energy.

content.questionText: Which type of cell has a true nucleus?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Eukaryotic cells have a nucleus.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Incorrect. Prokaryotic cells lack a true nucleus.

microCourses.title: Our Solar System at a Glance
microCourses.description: A quick tour of the planets and major bodies in our solar system.

content.title: The Sun: Our Star
content.markupContent:
### The Centerpiece

The Sun is a star that holds the Solar System together with its gravity. It provides light and heat essential for life on Earth.

content.title: Inner Planets (Terrestrial)
content.caption: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars - rocky planets closer to the Sun.

content.title: Outer Planets (Gas/Ice Giants)
content.caption: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune - large planets further from the Sun.

content.title: Asteroid Belt & Kuiper Belt
content.markupContent:
### Belts of Debris

*   **Asteroid Belt:** Located between Mars and Jupiter, full of rocky asteroids.
*   **Kuiper Belt:** Beyond Neptune, home to dwarf planets (like Pluto) and icy bodies.

content.title: What about Pluto?
content.markupContent:
### Dwarf Planet

In 2006, Pluto was reclassified as a 'dwarf planet' because it hasn't cleared its orbital neighborhood of other objects. It resides in the Kuiper Belt.

content.questionText: Which planet is known as the 'Red Planet'?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Mars gets its reddish appearance from iron oxide.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Incorrect. Think about the planet known for its rusty color.

microCourses.title: The Silk Road Essentials
microCourses.description: Explore the ancient trade network connecting East and West.

content.title: Key Goods Traded
content.markupContent:
### More Than Just Silk!

While silk from China was highly prized, many goods traveled the routes:

*   **East to West:** Silk, tea, spices, paper, gunpowder.
*   **West to East:** Horses, glassware, gold, silver, grapes.

It wasn't just goods, but also ideas!

content.title: Mapping the Routes
content.caption: A network of land and sea routes spanning thousands of miles.

content.questionText: Besides silk, what important invention traveled West along the Silk Road?
content.feedbackCorrect: Yes! Papermaking technology spread from China via the Silk Road.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Try again! Think about writing materials.

microCourses.title: Intro to the Roman Empire
microCourses.description: Key moments and figures from ancient Rome.

content.title: Pax Romana: Roman Peace
content.markupContent:
### Era of Stability

A long period of relative peace and minimal expansion (~27 BCE - 180 CE). Known for stability, infrastructure (roads, aqueducts), and prosperity across the vast empire.

content.title: Extent of the Empire
content.caption: At its height, the Roman Empire spanned from Britain to North Africa and the Middle East.

content.title: Key Figures: Julius Caesar
content.markupContent:
### Ambitious General & Statesman

Pivotal in the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Empire. Famous for his military campaigns in Gaul.

content.title: Key Figures: Augustus
content.markupContent:
### First Roman Emperor

Caesar's adopted son, Octavian, became Augustus. He ushered in the Pax Romana and reformed Roman society and government.

content.questionText: The 'Pax Romana' refers to a period of Roman...
content.feedbackIncorrect: Not quite. Think about the meaning of 'Pax'.

microCourses.title: JavaScript: Data Types Intro
microCourses.description: Understand the basic data types used in JavaScript.

content.title: What are Data Types?
content.markupContent:
Data types are classifications that specify which type of value a variable holds.

Think of them like categories for information (numbers, text, true/false, etc.). JavaScript needs to know the type to work correctly.

content.title: Strings: Representing Text
Numbers: Integers & Floats
content.markupContent:
### Numbers

Represent numeric values. Can be whole numbers (integers) or have decimals (floats).

```javascript
let age = 25;        // Integer
let price = 99.95;   // Float
```

*No quotes needed!*

content.title: Booleans: True or False
content.markupContent:
### Booleans

Represent logical values: `true` or `false`.

```javascript
let isActive = true;
let isLoggedIn = false;
```

Used heavily in decision making (if/else).

content.questionText: Which data type would you use to store a user's email address?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Email addresses are represented as text (strings).
content.feedbackIncorrect: Not quite. An email address is text information.

microCourses.title: HTML Fundamentals
microCourses.description: Learn the basic structure of web pages with HTML.

content.title: What is HTML?
content.markupContent:
### HyperText Markup Language

HTML is the standard markup language for creating web pages. It describes the *structure* of a web page using elements (tags).

content.title: Basic Structure
content.markupContent:
### The Skeleton Every HTML document has a basic structure: ```html Page Title

My First Heading

My first paragraph.

```

content.title: HTML Elements (Tags)
content.markupContent:
### Building Blocks HTML elements are represented by tags, usually in pairs like `

` and `

`. * `

` to `

`: Headings * `

`: Paragraphs * ``: Links (Anchors) * ``: Images

content.title: Nesting Elements
content.caption: Elements can be placed inside other elements, creating a hierarchy.

content.title: Attributes
content.markupContent: ### Providing More Info Attributes provide additional information about elements. ```html Link Text ``` *`href` and `src` are attributes.*

content.title: Comments
content.markupContent:
### Notes for Humans

HTML comments are ignored by the browser.

```html
<!-- This is a comment -->
```

content.questionText: Which tag is used to define the main content of an HTML document?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! The `<body>` tag contains the visible page content.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Incorrect. The `<head>` contains meta-information, and `<title>` sets the browser tab title.

microCourses.title: Intro to Python Syntax
microCourses.description: Get started with Python's basic commands and structure.

content.title: Printing Output
content.markupContent:
### Saying Hello

The `print()` function displays output to the console.

```python
print("Hello, LearnLoop!")
```

content.title: Variables
content.markupContent:
### Storing Data

Variables store data values. You don't need to declare the type explicitly.

```python
message = "This is a string"
count = 10
pi = 3.14
is_active = True
```

content.title: Indentation Matters!
content.markupContent:
### Whitespace is Significant

Python uses indentation (spaces or tabs) to define code blocks (like loops or if-statements). Consistency is key!

```python
if count > 5:
    print("Count is greater than 5") # Indented
print("Done") # Not indented
```

content.title: Comments
content.markupContent:
### Explaining Your Code

Comments start with `#` and are ignored by Python.

```python
# This is a single-line comment
message = "Hello" # This comment is after code
```

content.questionText: How do you print text to the console in Python?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! `print()` is the standard function for output.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Not quite. `console.log` is JavaScript, `echo` is often shell command.

microCourses.title: Cybersecurity Basics: Phishing
microCourses.description: Learn to recognize and avoid common phishing scams.

content.title: Common Red Flags
content.markupContent:
### Warning Signs:

*   Urgent calls to action ("Account suspended!")
*   Requests for sensitive info (passwords, SSN)
*   Generic greetings ("Dear Customer")
*   Suspicious links or attachments
*   Poor grammar/spelling
*   Mismatched sender email address

content.title: Hover Before You Click!
content.caption: Always hover your mouse over links (without clicking!) to see the actual destination URL.

content.questionText: An email asks for your password due to a 'security update'. Should you provide it?

options.text: No, legitimate services rarely ask for passwords via email
Only if the sender email looks correct

content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Never give out your password via email. It's a classic phishing tactic.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Incorrect! Legitimate organizations will almost never ask for your password directly in an email.

microCourses.title: Color Theory Basics
microCourses.description: Understand the fundamentals of color mixing, harmony, and contrast.

content.title: Primary, Secondary, Tertiary
content.markupContent:
### Color Categories:

*   **Primary:** Red, Yellow, Blue (Cannot be mixed from others)
*   **Secondary:** Green, Orange, Violet (Mixed from primaries)
*   **Tertiary:** Yellow-Orange, Red-Violet, etc. (Mixed from primary + secondary)

content.title: Hue, Saturation, Value (HSV)
content.caption: Understanding how to adjust Hue (the color itself), Saturation (intensity), and Value (lightness/darkness).

content.title: Color Harmony: Complementary
content.markupContent:
### Complementary Colors

Colors directly opposite each other on the color wheel (e.g., Red & Green, Blue & Orange). They create high contrast and visual excitement when placed side-by-side.

content.questionText: What type of colors are Red, Yellow, and Blue?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Red, Yellow, and Blue are the primary colors.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Incorrect. Think about the colors you start with to mix others.

microCourses.title: Intro to Graphic Design Principles
microCourses.description: Learn about balance, alignment, repetition, contrast, and hierarchy.

content.title: Alignment: Creating Order
content.markupContent:
### Alignment

Nothing should be placed arbitrarily. Every element should have a visual connection to another element on the page. Creates a cleaner, more organized look.

content.title: Repetition: Strengthening Unity
content.markupContent:
### Repetition

Repeat visual elements (colors, fonts, shapes) throughout the design. Helps to unify and strengthen the piece.

content.title: Contrast: Creating Emphasis
content.markupContent:
### Contrast

Making elements different to make them stand out (e.g., big vs. small text, light vs. dark colors). Helps draw the eye and create focal points.

content.title: Hierarchy: Guiding the Eye
content.markupContent:
### Visual Hierarchy

Arranging elements to show their order of importance. Using size, color, and placement to guide the viewer's eye through the content logically.

content.questionText: Using the same font style for all headings in a document is an example of which principle?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Repeating the font style creates unity and consistency.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Not quite. Think about which principle involves using elements consistently.

microCourses.title: Personal Finance: Budgeting 101
microCourses.description: Simple steps to create and stick to a personal budget.

content.title: Step 1: Track Your Spending
content.markupContent:
### Know Where Your Money Goes

For a week or a month, record *everything* you spend money on. Use an app, spreadsheet, or notebook. Be honest!

content.title: Step 2: Categorize Expenses
content.markupContent:
### Fixed vs. Variable

*   **Fixed:** Same amount each month (Rent/Mortgage, Car Payment)
*   **Variable:** Fluctuates (Groceries, Gas, Entertainment)
Group your tracked spending into categories.

content.title: Step 3: Set Goals & Make Adjustments
content.markupContent:
### Plan Your Spending

Compare your income to your expenses. Set limits for variable spending categories. Where can you cut back to save or pay off debt? (e.g., The 50/30/20 Rule: 50% Needs, 30% Wants, 20% Savings/Debt)

content.questionText: Your monthly rent payment is typically considered what type of expense?
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Fixed expenses generally stay the same each month.

microCourses.title: Effective Communication Snippets
microCourses.description: Quick tips for clearer conversations and active listening.

content.title: Active Listening: Pay Attention
content.markupContent:
### More Than Just Hearing

*   Put away distractions (phones!).
*   Make eye contact.
*   Nod and provide verbal cues ('uh-huh', 'I see').
*   Focus on understanding, not just waiting to speak.

content.title: Asking Clarifying Questions
content.markupContent:
### Avoid Misunderstandings

Don't assume you know what someone means. Ask questions like:

*   "Could you tell me more about...?"
*   "So, if I understand correctly, you're saying...?"
*   "What did you mean when you said...?"

content.questionText: Checking your phone while someone is talking to you is a sign of:
content.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Active listening requires minimizing distractions.
content.feedbackIncorrect: Incorrect. Paying attention is key to active listening.
